Introduction

A prescribed medicine is the most frequent treatment provided for patients in the NHS. Medicines must be prescribed, dispensed and administered safely and effectively. And, equally important, their storage and handling within NHS organisations must be safe, secure and comply with current legislation.
As such, the Trust must have a detailed system for safe, secure and legal storage of pharmaceuticals in clinical areas.

This policy is based on a risk management approach to determine storage systems which reduce the risk of accidental access as well as unauthorised intentional access, whilst balancing the need for urgent or immediate access in clinical emergency situations.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Describe the requirements for safe and secure storage of medication in clinical areas such as wards, clinics and other departments outside of pharmacy. This includes provision of services which may not be delivered on a Trust site.
Outline the process of maintenance and monitoring of temperature where medication is stored which require ambient or cold storage
This policy does not cover the storage of Controlled Drugs. Please refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
Definitions

table_items.text: Infusion, Irrigation and enteral fluids/feeds are usually supplied in labelled boxes. These are referred to as bulk fluids due to their physical size.

A drug to which its possession, supply and use are restricted by law and its possession may be an offence. Restrictions are described by what ‘Schedule' the drug is categorised under. In addition other medicines may be defined in our local policies to be treated as Controlled Drugs (e.g. concentrated potassium injection, epidural fluids).
In context of this policy, this is the moving of medication out of the original manufacturer/ dispensing container either into another container or storing loose within a storage facility.

This is the process of ordering and dispensing medicines in a format suitable for administration and following a pre-discharge check, suitable for use after discharge. Typically these are medicines which are labelled with directions to take for a specific named patient on the label.
A Registered Doctor whose name appears on the General Medical Council (GMC) Professional Register.

This is a date specified on medicines to denote the last day a medicine may be safely used. For example if the expiry date is 12/01/2022 then it is safe to use on 12/01/2022 but should not be used on 13/01/2022 or thereafter.

An unregistered practitioner who under general supervision undertakes practical nursing tasks and provides support to registered nurses in accordance with trust training. Some HCAs (i.e. Level 3) will have undertaken a relevant vocational qualification.

The definition of medicine is that used in the Medicines Act 1968 which uses the term ‘medicinal product'. That is, any substance administered for treating, preventing or diagnosing disease, for contraception, for inducing anaesthesia or modifying a normal physiological function. Medical gases are medicinal products. Medicines are grouped by legal classification and type. Nutritional supplements via the oral or enteral route are classed as foods. Parenteral nutrition is a medicine.
Refers to all Registered Operating Department Practitioners.

Overarching term for the services run by the Directorate of Pharmacy. This includes the dispensary, ward-based clinical services, technical services (chemotherapy unit / aseptic production), and procurement of medicines, clinical trials and quality assurance.
A Registered Pharmacist whose name appears on the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC) Professional Register.
A Registered Nurse (RN1 / RNA) or Registered Midwife (RM) whose name appears on the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) Professional Register.
Anyone registered with a professional body who is authorised to handle medicines, as detailed by their professional body and the Trust.
Senior professional in charge of a clinical area

Certain departments storing and using medicines do not have nurses or midwives present. In this case all responsibilities detailed within this document referring to the nurse or midwife-in-charge must be assigned to an alternative professional in charge. This may be a Radiographer, ODP, Medical Physicist, and Medical Technical Officer (MTO).
An excursion is where the temperature recorded is outside of the stated acceptable range.
All departments on all sites run by Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

This is a date specified on medicines to denote the date after which a medicine is no longer safe to use. For example if the use-by date is 12/01/2022 then it is safe to use on 11/01/2022 but should not be used on 12/01/2022 or thereafter
