Patient Safety and Quality Group / Risk and Compliance Group
Medicines Assurance Group
safe use of medicines.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Divisional Governance Groups
Pharmacy Board & Pharmacy Governance Group
Chief Pharmacist
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Site Pharmacy Operations Manager (or deputy)
Medication Safety & Governance Team
Chief Nurse
These roles may be delegated to the site Director of Nursing, though overall responsibility lies with the Chief Nurse.

Nurse/Midwife in charge of a clinical area - in each ward, unit, or department there shall be an appointed Nurse/Midwife (Ward/Dept. Manager) in charge. They may also be known as the Ward Senior Sister/Charge Nurse and they are responsible for:

Senior professional in charge of a clinical area - where a Nurse/Midwife is not present within a certain department, the responsibility can be assigned to another appropriate registered practitioner. This is agreed at the site MOSG and Pharmacy Head of Department for the site, involving the relevant Nursing leadership group. The identified job role will assume the responsibility to fulfil the same functions detailed under ‘Appointed Nurse/Midwife in charge'. Typically this would be the department manager.
Pharmacists, Pharmacy Technicians, Assistants & Pre-registration Pharmacy Professionals
Registered Nurses/Midwives/ODPs
Estates & Facilities department staff
MEMS department staff

Nursing/ Midwifery Students - must be given every opportunity to become proficient in medicines related activities under appropriate direct supervision. The supervising registered nurse/midwife has responsibility for medicine procedures at all times, including security & key holding.

Health Care Assistant (HCA) - are not permitted to be responsible for the security and use of medicines on the ward. As such they are not permitted to hold any key to medication storage facilities. However (please see competency- assessed medication storage assistant below).
Doctors
Competency-assessed medication storage assistant

This may be a staff member with other Trust roles (e.g. housekeeper, healthcare assistant etc.) who has undertaken the Trust approved competency framework for medication storage & monitoring in clinical areas.
Ordering and Replenishment of Medicines

Pharmacy distribution/stores staff are responsible for checking stock levels on most wards/clinical areas and arranging for the supply of stock medicines only according to determined minimum levels, at pre-determined intervals during the working week.
Some wards and departments are solely responsible for checking their own stock and ordering from pharmacy when necessary. This is locally agreed.
Stock lists are reviewed and agreed and not more than 6-monthly intervals as a collaboration between the ward manager (or equivalent) and the pharmacist responsible for the care area.

Additional controls are in place for the supply of fluids containing concentrated potassium (defined as a concentration of more than 40mmol in 1000ml). Please refer to the Safe Handling of Medicines Policy (or equivalent) for further information.

If wards/departments are using more stock than normal, the nurse in charge (or equivalent) is responsible for ensuring their team have ordered further supplies. This is done by contacting pharmacy distribution/stores, during opening hours.

Out of hours stock supplies of non-controlled drugs (except as outlined in the MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drug Policy) may be obtained from other wards/departments or the emergency drug cupboard until pharmacy re-opens.
Delivery and Receipt of Medicines to clinical areas
Deliveries are either received by hand from the pharmacy department (i.e. by member of ward team) or are delivered by a designated porter (or equivalent, depending on site).

Medicines other than controlled drugs or products liable to damage may also be delivered to the appropriate ward via the hospital air tube system (where available and functioning) which incorporates a secure facility at ward level (locked door or code to release the ‘POD' tube). Wards/departments are notified verbally by pharmacy when a medicine is sent where it is critically urgent or requires specific storage (i.e. refrigeration).

Medicines other than controlled drugs (see MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy) may be delivered to the appropriate wards or departments by a messenger, provided that they are packed in sealed tamper evident packages and are handed to the assigned registered nurse / midwife on arrival. Messengers may be the ward clerk, student nurse, department porter or healthcare assistant, and will always have their Trust ID badge on their person. Staff may be asked to sign for receipt of the medicines, depending on the type of medicine.

For delivery, pharmacy transport boxes are filled by pharmacy distribution staff, sealed with tamper-evident seals, labelled and then delivered to the wards by pharmacy porters (or equivalent staff) at pre-determined times.
Deliveries by pharmacy use designated pharmacy transportation receptacles (style differing by site):
Ambient (room temperature) medicines in standard pharmacy bags.
Fridge stored medicines in fridge-labelled pharmacy bags.
Cytotoxic medicines in cytotoxic-labelled pharmacy bags.
When a Pharmacy transport receptacle is left in a ward or department it is left sealed.

It is the responsibility of the nurse in charge of the ward (or equivalent) to ensure that all delivered medicines are unpacked promptly and stored securely on the ward/unit, in line with this policy.

Medicines from pharmacy must be locked away as soon as possible after their delivery to the ward and as such must not be left out on the preparation bench in drug preparation rooms, or anywhere else on the ward/department.

Deliveries, except controlled drugs, may be unpacked by registered nurses/ midwives/ ODPs. Alternatively this can be done by any member of staff who has undertaken, and passed, the Trust approved medication storage/management competencies. The ward/department manager will authorise this for their specific area/s of responsibility.
Pharmacy medication transit bags (or equivalent) either full or empty must not be left on the floor either inside or outside the ward area.
Controlled drugs

6.11.1  These are delivered in tamper-evident secured receptacles (differing by site) and must be signed for on delivery. These are always handed directly to a registered nurse/midwife (or equivalent) in the clinical area for immediate storage. Please refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drug Policy. Where CDs cannot be delivered via a secure receptacle the CD must be collected by ward staff from the pharmacy inpatient dispensary.
Fridge items

6.12.1  Fridge items must be placed in the ward/department fridge immediately on delivery. Fridge items are directly handed to a registered nurse/midwife (or equivalent) in the clinical area, or shown exactly where the delivery is.
Ambient storage

6.13.1 For all other ambient (room temperature) stored medicines the contents of the delivery box from pharmacy should be emptied into the appropriate locked storage cupboards on the day of delivery. A reasonable time frame is within 3-4 hours. This includes moving of bulk infusion fluids onto their designated racking (off the ground), in line with this policy.
6.13.2 Unwanted medicines (except controlled drugs) should be placed in a sealed Pharmacy transport box for return to Pharmacy.
Overall Storage Requirements
All medicines and items supplied by the Pharmacy must be stored in dedicated cupboards / medicine trolleys or specialist medicine refrigerators used solely for this purpose.
Alternative storage should be provided for non-medication items.
Each ward/department must have separate lockable and locked medicines storage facilities for each of the following:
Controlled Drug Cupboard/s (which is compliant with the Misuse of Drugs (Safe Custody) Regulations 1973), where required.
Internal Medicines Cupboard/s.
External Medicines Cupboard/facility.
Medicines (Pharmaceutical grade) Refrigerator / Freezer, where required.
All lockable storage facilities (cupboards, fridges etc.) must be locked when not in immediate use, including behind locked doors, except where outlined in this document (see section 28).
Exceptions

7.5.1 Where it is considered that exceptions to this policy are required risk assessments are undertaken and reviewed regularly. The risk assessment is a position of last resort and all reasonable efforts are required to facilitate storage of medicines in securely locked facilities, which may include modification of storage systems. Matters of convenience are not a basis for deviating from policy. All associated risk assessments are only valid where signed off by the Medication Safety Team on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist. These will be formally signed off by the Medicines Assurance Group.

7.5.2 Risk assessment will be proportionate to all risks (for example, reduce the risk of accidental access as well as unauthorised intentional access, whilst balancing the need for swift access to a limited number of medicines in clinical emergency situations) (HBN 14-02, 2021).
External Medicines

7.6.1  The external medicine cupboard is for the storage of medication used externally, e.g. mouthwashes, creams, lotions, rectal products. Where there are very few external preparations stocked, a designated labelled basket may be utilised where a full cupboard cannot be justified. This will be on approval from the site medication safety team.
Non-medicines and chemicals
7.7.1  Disinfectants, diagnostic reagents (including those for urine testing) and non- medicated dressings are stored separately from medicines.
Oral and Enteral Nutritional Supplements

7.8.1  These should have a designated separate storage. This is not required to be in the medication storage room unless deemed appropriate, in agreement with the Medication Safety Team. See section 24.
Fluids

7.9.1  Lockable area for boxes of intravenous fluids and sterile topical fluids (within their original boxed containers) – this may be on open racking within the locked, access controlled ‘medication store room'.
Bulk flammable solutions

7.10.1  These must be stored in lockable metal cupboards, which are appropriately labelled with a Flammable warning. Risk assessment will determine whether a fire- resistant cabinet is required - this may not be required for small quantities in clinical areas. All risk assessments are only valid where signed off by the Medication Safety Team on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist.
Radioactive Medicines
7.11.1  For radioactive medicines, security of storage is as advised by the radiation specialists from the Environment Agency.
Oral/Enteral Syringes

7.12.1 Clinical areas must store a sufficient supply of Trust approved purple oral/enteral syringes (or equivalent, as agreed by risk assessment for specific site) and medicine bottle bungs, where there is any possibility of oral/enteral liquid administration in that location.
7.12.2 These must be present within the drug preparation area to that of oral/enteral medicines, and in a range of sizes to administer different volumes easily.
7.12.3 Please see MSEPO-21128 Administration of Medicines Policy.
Insulin Syringes and subcutaneous insulin needles

7.13.1 Clinical areas must store a sufficient supply of Trust approved insulin syringes (with ‘unit' graduations) and stock supplies of subcutaneous insulin needles (for insulin pen devices), where there is any possibility of insulin being administered in that location.

7.13.2 Clinical areas must have subcutaneous safety needles available for healthcare staff to use AND a supply of non-safety needles to offer patients who self- administer their insulin (see MSEPO-21129 Adult self-administration of medicines SAM policy).
7.13.3 These must be present within the drug preparation area close to that of insulin (i.e. near fridge).
7.13.4 Please see MSEPO-21128 Administration of Medicines Policy.
Designated Medication Room (‘Clean utility')
These rooms should be sufficiently away from patients and the public. In practice this means that the room has a lockable door which is always locked when not in use.
Doors should lock automatically on closing, and not require pulling shut to lock.
The contents of the room must not be visible from an outside window at ground level.
This should be in a position to allow continuous surveillance and maximum security against unauthorised entry.
No cupboards or fridges should be near major sources of heat (such as radiators). Where radiators exist, near cupboards they must be turned off.
Refrigerators should not be installed in areas with large fluctuations in temperature as this may affect performance.
No medicines, in any circumstances, are permitted to be stored in sluice (dirty utility) rooms, or under sinks.

There must be good lighting levels provided for storage and worktop areas. Refer to Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers LG02/19. Lighting guide 02: Lighting for healthcare premises (HBN 14-02, 2021).

Work-surfaces and the general environment must be clean (in line with Trust infection control standards) and tidy to facilitate the safe and efficient preparation of medicines. Sufficient space to allow safe working is required, especially for the safe preparation of injectable medicines. Work surfaces should be easily cleaned and not cluttered. At least two metres of such worktop is required for medicine preparation in a typical Trust ward area (HBN 14-02, 2021).
New medication room installations, refurbishments, or upgrades

8.10.1 Medication rooms in use are assessed at least yearly and signed off as fit for purpose in terms of sizing/suitability for workload being undertaken. Exceptions are reported into Medicines Assurance Group, to the appropriate division and Risk and Compliance.

8.10.2 It is essential to ensure that planning and design of new premises incorporates appropriate facilities and sufficient capacity for the safe and secure storage of medicines. The Trust Chief Pharmacist (or deputy), local security management specialist, Medication Safety Officer (or medication safety team) and relevant lead nurses with other relevant healthcare professionals must be involved at an early stage. Proposed spaces must be consulted with pharmacy at the earliest opportunity to ensure they will be compliant, including of sufficient space.

8.10.3 All new installations, refurbishments or upgrades of existing medication rooms must be compliant with the Trust Medication Room Specification document, published on the intranet. The specification meets national recommendations and guidance (including the relevant NHS Health Building Notes).

8.10.4 All refurbishments and upgrades must meet the Trust specification requirements. The construction of medicine cupboards in medication rooms must be made of metal in order to comply with BS 2881. Existing installations that do not comply need not be replaced immediately but when plans for upgrading are being prepared. (HBN 14-02, 2021).

8.10.5 All drug room design plans must be formally approved for compliance by designated pharmacy staff (i.e. the site medication safety team) before placing orders for storage systems or security arrangements. Failure to do so may, and has, resulted in provision of unsafe, inefficient and potentially illegal storage solutions that may be costly to retrofit (HBN 14-02, 2021).

8.10.6 Whenever a new room/space is considered for storing medicines the site Medication Safety Team in pharmacy must be contacted for advice, approval and logging as a designated medication storage area before medicines are moved.
Secure keys, locks & access codes
Responsibility
9.1.1  The ward/department manager is responsible, at all times, for the overall security
and storage of medicine on the ward or department. The nurse/midwife in charge
of each shift should ensure that medicines are stored in a secure fashion in line
with this document. Breaches of any of these standards may be a disciplinary
matter and also require completion of an incident report.
Safe Custody
9.2.1 The following applies to all areas except for Operating Departments (Theatres). Please see chapter 28 and the MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs policy.

9.2.2 The keys for the medicine trolley and all medicine and controlled drug cupboards must be held on their person by a registered nurse, registered midwife or other authorised practitioner, approved by pharmacy.
Keys must remain on the ward at all times, to ensure access to medicines is not delayed.
Cupboard keys or open cupboards/ trolleys must never be left unattended.

At each shift change the known number of sets of keys must be counted in and back out to the next shift to ensure all sets of keys are accounted for and are on the person of the relevant authorised staff.
Access to keys/ rooms
9.6.1 Keys must never be surrendered to anyone without a valid Trust photo identification badge, regardless of whether in a uniform or not.

9.6.2 Staff must never hand over cupboard keys, give access codes to, or open doors or cupboards for others unless they are clear that the person to whom they are giving access is authorised to handle medicines within the Trust.
Electronic locking systems

9.7.1 Electronic locking systems that secure areas used to store medicines may use electronic keys, swipe cards or fingerprint and other technology that open the lock and lock immediately on closing the door.
9.7.2 These systems allow cards or keys to be allocated to individual authorised persons, enabling audit of access to take place.
9.7.3 Any new system considered on any site must be on approval from the Chief Pharmacist, before procurement.
Keypads/Digilocks
9.8.1 Where key pads are used on entry doors, the codes are changed at not less than 6-monthly intervals such as by the Estates & Facilities department changing codes on a rolling schedule.
9.8.2 Standard keypads where a number is shared with multiple users are not suitable for medicine cupboards.
9.8.3 The code to the keypads must never be on display anywhere.

Pharmacy staff checking ward stocks of medicines may be provided with a key for this purpose. (N.B. only registered pharmacists and registered pharmacy technicians may be in possession of the Controlled Drug cupboard key).
Duplicate sets of keys
9.10.1 Risk assessments are undertaken to determine the number of key copies and safe custody arrangements for these.

9.10.2 The senior nurse/midwife for the unit (or equivalent) must formally identify how many sets of key are held on each ward or department. This number is the number of sets that are verified as handed over at shift-changes.

9.10.3 There is no restriction on number of sets of keys, and can vary by site. The number of sets of keys must be proportionate to the number of nursing/midwifery staff working in the area to deliver safe, responsive medication supply to patients. For example a ward with three nurses on duty may have three sets. The Medication Safety Team on each site can advise wards/departments. This does not include Controlled Drug keys (see below).

9.10.4 A labelled duplicate set of all keys (including CD cupboards) should also be provided to pharmacy by the nurse / midwife in charge. Pharmacy keeps a record of duplicate sets of keys which it holds.
9.10.5 The availability of duplicate sets in pharmacy varies across sites and reflects the degree to which nursing/midwifery staff provide these for emergency use.

9.10.6 This is used to track the issuing and return of keys to the department when they are used. Where issuing of duplicate keys to the same location occurs more than three times, all medication locks in that department are recommended to be changed.
Controlled drug cupboard keys
9.11.1 Please also refer to the MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.

9.11.2 These keys must always be in possession of a registered Nurse or Midwife (or equivalent). The ward/department manager must ensure that there are systems in place to ensure that this key/s is secure and is accounted for regularly during the shift.

9.11.3 Controlled Drug cupboard keys will be on a separate set to those of main medicine cupboard keys. Only associated keys (e.g. to open CD deliveries, PCA cassette keys etc.) may be on the same keyring. Where there is an operational reason to keep keys together with other drug keys this will be risk assessed by the department and approved by the site Pharmacy Head of Department.
9.11.4 Only one set of CD keys is permitted in any clinical location.
9.11.5 Keeping more than one set of CD keys in any clinical area is considered exceptional and only agreeable in writing from the Chief Pharmacist (Accountable Officer for Controlled drugs).
Loss of keys

9.12.1 If it is suspected that a member of staff may have gone off duty with keys to medication storage locations (i.e. cupboards), they must be contacted by telephone as soon as possible and asked to return the keys immediately.

9.12.2 In the exceptional event that the member of staff cannot return to the ward/department arrangement should be made for it to be collected from them (e.g. another nurse or authorised person to be in possession of medicine keys).
9.12.3 It is not acceptable practice to retain drug keys until the next span of duty. Without exception drug keys must be returned without delay.

9.12.4 In the event that drugs keys go missing or are lost the specialty matron must be informed for urgent investigation, and reported to the site Pharmacy Operations Manager (or deputy) by the next working day.
9.12.5 Where Controlled Drugs Cupboard keys are lost, Pharmacy must be informed immediately. Please refer MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy for further information.
9.12.6 For all loss of keys, regardless of whether returned, an incident report must be submitted by the Nurse/Midwife-in-charge.
Broken or defective locks

9.13.1 It is the sole responsibility of the nurse/midwife in charge (or equivalent) to ensure that the lock is replaced and operational and that this is managed and escalated (in event of any delays) urgently.
9.13.2 For Controlled Drug Locks, refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
9.13.3 Nurse/Midwife-in-charge must place urgent requests for replacement locks with facilities – informing them it is for ‘drug cupboards'.
9.13.4 Facilities Department are responsible for fitting a replacement drug cupboard lock within an agreed timeframe.
9.13.5 Nurse/Midwife-in-charge to submit an incident report, detailing the exact location.
Storage of Containers

All medicines, including intravenous fluids, enteral feeds and frequently used small volume injections in ampoules (such as dental cartridges, sodium chloride 0.9% and water for injection) must be stored in their original packaging and not loose or decanted.

Decanting is the presence of loose ampoules; blister strips of tablets etc. into any container (e.g. plastic containers, disposable cups, and boxes) and is NOT permitted in any cupboard or trolley. The only exception to this is where the item is supplied only as a singular item by pharmacy and is not appropriate to package into a box (e.g. rarely used infusion bag).
Retaining in original containers allows:
Easier identification of stock
Adequate stock rotation including ease of reading expiry dates
Elimination of mixed storage of different medicines known to be contributory to mis-selection errors.
This practice reduces preventable medication incidents.

Where this is not possible, risk assessments are undertaken and reviewed regularly. The risk assessment is a position of last resort and all reasonable efforts are required to facilitate storage of medicines in original containers, which may include modification of storage systems. Matters of convenience are not a basis on its own for decanting of medication. All associated risk assessments are only valid where signed off by the Medication Safety Team on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist. These will be formally signed off by the Medicines Assurance Group.
Oral liquid medicines should be able to be stored upright after opening.

Pharmacy staff are responsible for the clear labelling of containers where they are packed down by the pharmacy department. Packing down of medicines must never be undertaken by non-pharmacy staff. Any concerns with labelling must be referred immediately back to the site pharmacy dispensary, without exception.

Once a dose of any medicine has been removed from its container (or outer wrap for fluid bags) it shall never be returned. If not required it shall be discarded, according to the appropriate waste disposal procedure.
For controlled drugs please refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
Storage Segregation

Medicines with differing routes/methods of administration, or which look alike/sound alike are stored separately or segregated to minimise selection errors. These are determined by pharmacy and communicated clearly in the clinical area.

Risk assessments undertaken with involvement of the Medication Safety Team consider the latest nationaland local safety guidance to further segregate medicines at high risk of selection and/or administration error.
For example – similar looking infusion containers (e.g. ‘polyfusor') are particularly prone to mis-selection and different drugs should be clearly segregated (i.e. phosphate, mannitol etc.).
Stock Rotation

Medication must be stored and rotated within cupboards and refrigerators ensuring stocks with shorter expiry dates are used first. Opened stock must be stored in front of unopened and longer-dated stock.

Patient's own medicines requiring refrigeration must be stored neatly in the ward medicine refrigerator. Arrangements for ensuring such medicines move with patients, if appropriate, on discharge or ward transfer must be in place.

It is recommended that ward/dept. staff undertake a weekly check for medication no longer required, or expired medication. Refrigerators must especially be checked as storage space is limited. Pharmacy staff must be notified who will arrange for the return or disposal of the medication back to the pharmacy department.
Unopened, unwanted items should not be removed from the refrigerator until arrangements have been made to ensure adequate transport.
Refrigerated medicines must not be left in the pharmacy transit boxes (unless they are expired and are for disposal).
Expiry Date Checking
Expiry date checking of all stock on the ward is the responsibility of nurse/midwife in charge or equivalent.

Pharmacy staff may assist in this, within the course of their practice, but this does not replace the need for nurse/midwife-in-charge to provide assurance that complete checks are carried out. Pharmacy staff cannot assume responsibility for stock and usage of drugs in locations outside of pharmacy departments.
Record keeping

13.3.1  Routine expiry date checks are required at least monthly and must be evidenced though completion of the monthly log in the designated Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet. This is issued annually by pharmacy.
Identification of short-expiry medicines
13.4.1 Items shortly due to expire should be easily identifiable and removed from storage upon expiry. ‘Use now short dated' (or equivalent) stickers are available from pharmacy to assist with this.
13.4.2 Unwanted items must be returned to pharmacy for disposal.
13.4.3 The use of a short-dated list is recommended on storage cupboards/ refrigerators etc. to assist with this.
13.4.4 All staff should know how to interpret ‘expiry date' and ‘use by date'. Please refer to the definitions of this policy.
Expiry dates once-opened
13.5.1 All liquids and insulin must be labelled with date opened. Labels for this purpose are available and can be ordered from pharmacy, on request.
13.5.2 Expiry dates, once opened, unless otherwise stated on the label are:

table_items.text: 4 weeks (including at room temperature) Note: this expiry is simplified for all insulin for ease in clinical areas.

data.text: 13.5.3 Nurses and Midwives should be aware that these expiries are a guide only and that expiry dates should never be assumed.
13.5.4 Some products (including tablets and capsules) have a reduced expiry once their special container is opened. The medicine container label must be consulted each time.
13.5.5 Where pharmacy makes an inpatient supply, it will include a revised expiry date, where applicable, on the dispensing label/container.

13.5.6 Note that reconstituted antibiotic syrups and bottled sip feeds (i.e. Procal Shot® / Calogen®) have much shorter expiries of only a few days. Always refer to the product label. If in doubt, ward/department staff must contact pharmacy for advice.
Refrigerated / Frozen Storage

Ward/department staff must identify the storage requirements for any medicines when they take receipt of them. Where refrigeration is necessary, this must be done immediately upon receipt. Some medicines have a maximum time for unrefrigerated storage and this must not be exceeded. This is stated on the label.

If medicines requiring refrigeration are not stored appropriately their potency may be affected and staff must contact pharmacy regarding their suitability for use as soon as possible. Such medicines must not be administered to patients until advice has been sought.
Individual medicines requiring storage in a refrigerator are marked or labelled ‘Store in a refrigerator' or state the exact temperature range for storage on the manufacturers packaging.
Frozen items will be similarly labelled ‘freezer' or state the exact temperature range.

Medicines should only be removed from the fridge as necessary prior to administration to the patient. The single dose prepared should be allowed to warm to room temperature for a short period of time only to avoid discomfort to the patient.

Opened insulin can be stored at room temperature in the patient-specific locked bedside medicine locker. A 4-week expiry applies from the day removed from the fridge for all insulin. This expiry is applied to all insulin in the organisation for consistency.
Using Medication Refrigerators/Freezers
All principles in this section referring to refrigerator equally apply to freezer storage.
Appropriate storage facilities must be available for the storage of refrigerated/freezer items up to the point of administration of the medicine.

All refrigerators or freezers used for storing medicines must be of pharmaceutical grade. Pharmacy provides advice on suitable recommended models for purchase, in line with the most recent regulatory guidance.
Refrigerators with glass doors are preferred because contents can be seen without opening the fridge unnecessarily.
Refrigerators/freezers must not be sited near a radiator or other heat source that might affect their working, and should be appropriately ventilated.
Sufficient space must be maintained between medicines and internal surfaces of the fridge to allow adequate air flow. This means that the fridge/freezer:
must be large enough for the needs of that location
are not overloaded to allow air circulation.
medicines are not to be stored in contact with the sides or bottom of the fridge/freezer
This helps maintain a more even temperature regulation.
Fridges and freezers used for the storage of medicines are not used to store any other items (i.e. pathology samples, staff drinks and food), in all circumstances.

Nutritional oral supplements (e.g. sip feeds) are bulky. They may be stored in a general domestic ward fridge. Oral sip feeds are not legally classed as medicines. It is not recommended these are stored in medicines refrigerators as they restrict access by non-registrants caring for patients.
Where at all possible they should be sited inside the medication room.
All Fridges must be lockable and locked when not in immediate use.
Power supply
15.11.1 The power supply to the refrigerator must be adequately shielded to avoid accidental disconnection.
15.11.2 Ideally, the supply of electricity to the refrigerator/freezer is via hard-wired fuse (fused spur).

15.11.3 If available the fridge should be linked to an emergency power supply. Where this is not possible the switch on the socket must be adapted by a qualified Trust electrician to reduce risk of accidentally switching off (e.g. socket cover / extension bracket to avoid objects being pushed against switch). These are used in the pharmacy technical services aseptic unit.
15.11.4 Staff must not disconnect the fridge/freezer from the power supply at any time.
Maintenance

15.12.1 The interior of the fridge/freezer must be kept clean and any spillages cleaned up immediately. They must be cleaned using the appropriate methods and cleaning solution, in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.

15.12.2 Pharmaceutical fridges are usually a ‘frost free' model and will not require defrosting. However, occasionally older models may require defrosting. The fridge should be defrosted in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Medication must be stored in an alternative medication-only refrigerator during the process, e.g. a nearby ward. Ice must not be allowed to build up within the fridge or freezer as this reduces effectiveness and can lead to freezing of medicines. The ward/department manager is responsible for ensuring this does not happen.
15.12.3 Records of all servicing and defrosting should be kept in the clinical area where the Fridge/freezer is located. Ward/department managers must store these records safely.
15.12.4 Electrical safety testing, known as portable appliance testing (PAT) must be completed on all fridges/freezers annually. This is managed by the estates & facilities department.
15.12.5 Integrated thermometers must be regularly re-calibrated and evidence of this must exist if they are being used for monitoring purposes (see temperature monitoring below).
Refrigerator / Freezer Temperature Monitoring
Acceptable temperature range
Items stored in a refrigerator must be kept within the range of 2°C to 8°C.
Items stored in a freezer must be kept within the range of -10°C to -40°C.

16.1.1 Temperatures may temporarily increase above the acceptable range – this happens when the door is opened to remove/stock medicines. This is normal, though must be minimised. Therefore temperature monitoring includes minimum, maximum and current temperature monitoring to enable assessment of patterns over time to determine whether medicines storage is safe.
Accidental disconnection of the electrical supply
16.2.1 If the refrigerator temperature has remained inside the range of 2-8°C or freezer temperature range remained between -10 to -40°C:
Reconnect the power supply and no further action is required.
Record the current fridge/freezer temperature and the time of recording and keep the doors closed.
16.2.2 If the temperature has gone out of range then follow guidance for temperature excursion within this policy.
Please refer troubleshooting guides for managing common issues with temperature monitoring, available on the intranet.
The temperature of the refrigerator or freezer is monitored on each working day using a calibrated maximum-minimum thermometer.
In the absence of fridge/freezer thermometer calibration they must be fitted, after installation, with the Trust-approved calibrated minimum/maximum thermometer.

These are provided by pharmacy and replacements are issued when the calibration expiry is reached. The Nurse-in-charge (or equivalent) is responsible for ensuring the monitoring and maintaining of this device.

Routine temperature monitoring is required at least daily and must be evidenced though completion of the log in the designated Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet. This should be done at approximately the same time each day so that consecutive readings are not too close together.
The current, maximum and minimum temperature must be recorded. Action must be taken where minimum and/or current temperatures are out of range and documented within the booklet.
Separate documentation exists for freezers.

Once the daily thermometer readings are read and recorded, the thermometer must always be reset. This must be done for every working day of the department. A weekly check should be undertaken by the ward/department manager for each area for assurance. When the department is closed, the entry for that date on the monitoring log must state ‘CLOSED'.
The record of temperature must be retained for at least two years. These records must be available for audit.
Temperature records must detail corrective actions where a temperature excursion has occurred.
Temperature excursions
An excursion is where the temperature recorded is outside of the stated range.
Ward/department managers must be made aware when temperatures first start to fall outside the acceptable temperature range. This includes too cold as well as too warm.
Actions must be taken immediately to try to identify the problem and bring the temperature back into range.
For items stored in a refrigerator this is when:
Any temperature recording is below 2°C.
Current temperature recording is above 8°C.
Note: Maximum temperatures will exceed 8°C because the fridge door probably has been opened in the preceding  hours to access medicines.
For items stored in a freezer when:
Any temperature recording is above -10°C (i.e. getting warmer)
Current temperature recording is below -40°C
Actions to be taken when temperature out of range

16.9.1 Comprehensive troubleshooting guidance exists on the Trust intranet for a range of out of range situations. These must be followed in the first instance. These detail the common issues identified with temperature monitoring.
16.9.2 IMMEDIATE ACTION by NURSE/MIDWIFE
Check if there is an obvious cause that can be remedied? For example, has the thermometer or probe been positioned incorrectly or is it damaged/ battery empty? If unsure call pharmacy.
Check if fridge has been accidently switched off or obviously no longer functioning. If so, reconnect power supply.
Had the door been inappropriately left open? Close door and keep closed.
Is the fridge over stocked?
Does the fridge need defrosting?
Re-record temperatures after 30minutes. If the problem is resolved, no further action needed. Ensure action taken is documented in the Medicine storage monitoring booklet.
Tell facilities to log call as related to ‘drug fridge/freezer temperature'.
Log the call in the Medicine Storage monitoring booklet.
Submit an incident report, if not yet completed.
Reducing expiry date advice from pharmacy
16.10.1 A reduction in expiry date or disposal of stock may be necessary when a temperature excursion has taken place.

16.10.2 Pharmacy staff will collect a list of all medicines stored in the fridge and consult individual product literature and stability data published by UK medicines information – published via specialist pharmacy services website, and drug manufacturers. This must be done for each individual product since these medicines are more susceptible to temperature damage than ambient-stored medicines. Pharmacy must be contacted for advice on every occasion because manufacturers' and specialist advice can change.

16.10.3 Any stock with a reduced expiry has a ‘use now short dated' (or equivalent) sticker affixed by pharmacy and new expiry written on the container. The manufacturer expiry date is crossed through.

16.10.4 All temperatures must continue to be monitored, either in the repaired fridge/freezer/warmer or a replacement one to ensure on-going storage, and any adjustment in expiry dates made, remains appropriate.
Stock management after temperature excursion

16.11.1 Once a decision is made for each medicine by pharmacy, details will be obtained by pharmacy staff on what stock needs replacing and any reduced stock holding needed for the temporary storage location identified (i.e. neighbouring ward fridge).
16.11.2 A pharmacy staff member will communicate this verbally and in writing to the ward/dept. manager (or deputy) within one working day.
Medication cupboards – Ambient (Room Temperature) storage

Cupboards and closed storage units in which medicines are stored and/or the rooms that accommodate these are lockable and locked when not in immediate use (except where outlined specifically in this policy).

Where possible, and for new storage facilities, cupboards for the storage of medicines comply with the current British Standard 2881. Existing storage must be of a standard approved by the site Medication Safety Team in pharmacy.

Where possible, and for new storage facilities, locks for cupboards (except patients' medicine cabinets/lockers) comply with the current British Standard as a minimum. The current British Standard is BS 3621.
All cupboards must be securely attached to a wall with all parts (including doors and locks) in good condition. These must be accessible without risk of danger to ward/department staff.

Where computer-controlled cabinets are used for medicines they will provide at least the same level of security as traditional lockable cupboards. These can only be approved and introduced via senior pharmacy staff authorisation and oversight.
Only ‘stock' drugs that the ward/department is permitted to hold, on authorisation from pharmacy, may be stored in these.

Occasionally ‘temporary stock' is supplied (for some sites), though these must only be kept on the ward for as long as needed for the specific patient, before returning to pharmacy. It is considered poor practice to keep temporary stock, no longer needed, because they may be reutilised by pharmacy for patient care elsewhere, reduces wastage from expired items, and keeps cupboards uncluttered.

Tablets, liquids and injections will be clearly segregated from each other and organised by drug name (not brand name).There must be sufficient space for this to be done in a tidy manner to facilitate stock checks.
Some medicines may be segregated for reasons of patient safety such as under the advice of the department of pharmacy.

There will be a supply of injectable flushing solutions as appropriate for the clinical area and these will be clearly segregated from each other. They must remain within their original packaging. Cannula ‘flushes' from ampoules are legally medicines. As such all boxes, opened or not, must be stored in locked cupboards.
Patient-specific labelled medicines must never be mixed with stock medicines. This includes the storage of discharge medicines and patient's own medicines.

When medicines are no longer required arrangements must be made for returning to pharmacy using the returns process. This is especially important for non-stock supplies of medicines which could be re-utilised elsewhere in the hospital.
Ambient (Room) Temperature Monitoring
Acceptable temperature range
18.1.1   Room temperature is also referred to as ‘ambient' temperature storage.
Items stored in ‘ambient' locations must be kept within the range 15°C – 25°C.

A limited list of locations may be approved by pharmacy as ‘ambient up to 30°C'. These storage areas are reviewed and authorised by pharmacy with this temperature range. They usually stock only infusion fluids and no other medicines.
The same principles apply exactly for drug room temperature monitoring as for fridges. The Trust-approved thermometers can be switched between room and fridge monitoring for this purpose.

Routine temperature monitoring is required at least daily and must be evidenced though completion of the log in the designated Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet. This must be done at approximately the same time each day.
18.3.1 The current, maximum and minimum temperature must be recorded. Action must be taken where out of range and documented within the booklet.
18.3.2 Remote monitoring
In some locations, and especially on the Southend site, drug room temperatures only may be monitored remotely by the Estates & Facilities department.
The Estates & Facilities department is responsible for managing temperature excursions in same way as nursing, in accordance with this policy.

The site pharmacy department has a directory of all locations where temperatures are remotely monitored. Designated signs in medicine storage areas inform nurse/midwifery staff where room temperature monitoring by them is not required.
Ambient temperature excursions
An excursion is where the temperature recorded is outside of the stated range.
Ward/department managers must be made aware when temperatures first start to fall outside the acceptable temperature range.
Actions must be taken immediately to try to identify the problem and bring the temperature back into range.
18.4.1  There are potentially 2 different scenarios with ambient temperature excursions.
Different actions are required to manage these situations.

Comprehensive troubleshooting guidance exists on the Trust intranet for a range of out of range situations. These must be followed in the first instance. These detail the common issues identified with temperature monitoring.
Action to take for an ISOLATED room temperature excursion
(One-off event e.g. air conditioning stops working)
18.5.1 Ward/department managers must be made aware when temperatures first start to exceed the acceptable temperature range.

18.5.2 It is acceptable that the drug room ‘ambient' temperature may temporarily exceed 25°C for up to 7 days consecutively (or exceeding 30°C for up to 3 days consecutively) without causing a significant pharmaceutical quality risk (damage to quality of medicines), and therefore patient harm risk. However, actions must
be taken immediately to try to reduce the temperature. Never wait for 3 or 7 days – as this can affect decision making on future use of medicines, and wastage.
18.5.3 Temperature exceeds 25°C: IMMEDIATE ACTION by NURSE/MIDWIFE
Check if there is an obvious cause that can be remedied? For example, has the thermometer or probe been positioned incorrectly or is it damaged/ battery empty? If unsure call pharmacy.
Check if any air conditioning has been accidently switched off.
Had the door / windows been inappropriately left open (for air-conditioned rooms)?
Tell facilities to log call as related to ‘drug room temperature'.
Record the call in the Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet.
Submit an incident report.
18.5.4 IMMEDIATE ACTION by PHARMACY

Pharmacy staff must escalate communication from ward/department to appropriate designated pharmacy technicians/assistants for medicine storage. This must be done verbally as minimum to ensure there are no undue delays.

Pharmacy will log instance on a spreadsheet once notified (as above). The designated staff will liaise with ward/department periodically (i.e. daily) regarding the current temperature status. No other actions are required by pharmacy.
18.5.5 ACTION BEYOND 7 DAYS (>25°C) or 3 DAYS (>30°C) by PHARMACY
Action to take for REPEATED or SUSTAINED temperatures above range
(Room above 25°C consistently or is expected to be at multiple time periods across season, including heat waves)

Pharmacy has a log of locations where temperatures are expected to be above range. This is based on historical information and notifications when rooms have become warm. Therefore it is important pharmacy is always notified immediately so actions are taken as early as possible.

Actions must be taken when clinical room temperatures rise above 25°C consistently. Historical information about a locations temperature (particularly in warmer seasons/heat waves) allows pharmacy to proactively plan and take pre-emptive action before nurse/midwife notification is expected to happen.
Temperature exceeds 25°C repeatedly:
18.7.1 IMMEDIATE ACTION by NURSE/MIDWIFE
Check if there is an obvious cause that can be remedied? For example, has the thermometer or probe been positioned incorrectly or is it damaged/ battery empty? If unsure call pharmacy.
Check if any air conditioning has been accidently switched off.
Had the door / windows been inappropriately left open (for air-conditioned rooms)?
Tell facilities to log call as related to ‘drug room temperature'.
Log the call in the temperature monitoring booklet.
Submit an incident report.
Cooling should be implemented and functioning within 7 days.
18.7.2 IMMEDIATE ACTION by PHARMACY

Designated Pharmacy technicians will determine the appropriate action in line with this document. Where cooling cannot be implemented or cannot achieve below 25°C within 7 days, pharmacy staff will attend the ward/department to assess. Out of hours the oncall pharmacist and/or senior pharmacist onsite will liaise with the designated pharmacy technicians for any action required on the next full working day (Monday-Friday).
Immediate pharmacy actions on notification of temperature excursion

18.8.1  Pharmacy staff will consistently respond to all temperature excursion enquiries in the same way in accordance with Appendix 2: Pharmacy action when notified of an ambient temperature excursion.
Reducing expiry date advice from pharmacy – ‘Ambient' drug storage

18.9.1 The reduction of medication expiry dates will be considered if there is deemed to be a pharmaceutical quality risk following pharmacy staff assessment of the situation. The reduction will not be based on a single temperature excursion but on the predicted duration of exposure of the medicines to high temperatures.
18.9.2 Expiry date reduction processes will be undertaken at the beginning of a high temperature excursion period and repeated again at the end of the high temperature excursion.
18.9.3 Pharmacy staff will consistently respond to all temperature excursion enquiries in the same way in accordance with Appendix 4: Reducing Expiry Dates of Ambient Stored Medicines.

18.9.4 It is recommended that if an expiry reduction is deemed necessary; following a risk assessment, a blanket reduction of 6 months rule will be applied. This single point decision allows for further possible excursions (i.e. room expected to be hot for entire summer season).

18.9.5 This reduces the need to continually reduce expiry dates following multiple single temperature excursions. The blanket reduction is based on pharmacy quality assurance advice and pragmatic practicality to deliver this across the Trust site/s.
18.9.6 All temperatures must continue to be monitored to ensure the blanket reduction in expiry date remains appropriate.
18.9.7 Occasionally some medicines will become expired once the expiry date reduction has been applied. If this is the case, stock is removed and new stock supplied from pharmacy.

18.9.8 Not all medicines will be reduced in expiry date. This will depend on the mean temperature of the drug room and the specific storage range of the medication concerned. In general bulky infusion fluids will not be reduced in expiry unless temperatures in excess of 30°C are consistently recorded.

18.9.9 High cost, limited stock availability and controlled drug medicines will be assessed by pharmacy staff on an individual drug basis which may include using quality control calculations to determine if they can have expiry extended.
Medication Trolley Storage
All medicine trolleys must be lockable and locked. Key pad locks are not recommended for trolleys and should not be used.

All medicine trolleys must be secured at an anchor point (i.e. a point at which trolleys can be secured to the floor or wall) when not in use. Since some staff may access a drug room that are not authorised to handle medicines, this includes within a locked drug room.
The trolley must not be left unattended during the medicine round.
Medicines no longer in use (e.g. ‘temporary' stock items, where used) must be returned to pharmacy if present in the trolley.

The trolley should be organised alphabetically by drug name (not brand name). There should be sufficient space for this to be done in a tidy manner to facilitate stock checks and ease of identification. Where drug-round specific trolleys are used, it should be packed neatly, using whole containers.
Any shelving around the trolley must not be used for the storage of medicines. Medicines must only ever be stored within a locked cupboard, or within the locked trolley compartment.
Trolleys must never contain patient-specific labelled-for-discharge medicines. These should be placed in the designated patient-specific locked bedside medicine lockers.
Bedside medicines cupboard

This cupboard is for the storage of patient-specific labelled medicines, on wards operating a ‘dispensing for discharge' system. These will be installed either on the wall near the bed or are attached/integrated in bedside cupboard units.
Only patient's own medicines and medicines labelled with directions (i.e. ready for discharge dispensed from the hospital pharmacy or TTA packs), for that specific patient, may be stored in these.

All medication must be locked away except for GTN spray, reliever inhalers (salbutamol / terbutaline), nicotine inhalators or gum, large emollient creams requiring regular application and artificial saliva gels (e.g. bioextra® / oralbalance®) which can be kept with the patient.

Each lockable cupboard must only be accessible by registered nurse/midwives and authorised pharmacy staff. Access will be by traditional key or a pharmacy approved automated card/key fob for automated locks.
Where traditional keys are used each locker must have an individual and master key. Master keys will be held by the registered nurse/midwife and also the ward pharmacy team.

Where the patient is self-administering (in accordance with MSEPO-21129 Adult self-administration of medicines SAM policy) then they may be given an individual key for that specific locker. This must be returned before discharge or patient transfer.
The master key (or master automated card/ master key fob) must never be given to a patient where an individual key/card/fob is not available.
If there is an access issue to keys or automated bedside lockers this must be it must be escalated and estates & facilities department immediately.
Estates and facilities should be advised to log call as related to ‘drug/medication bedside locker' + bed number quoted.
Inform pharmacy and identify alternative secure storage arrangement.
Submit an incident report.
On discharge or patient transfer, the locker contents must be completely emptied ready for the next patient occupant.
In areas where these cabinets are not provided, other arrangements must be made for the secure storage of patients' own medication.

Within A&E it may not be possible for patients own medication to be stored in a ward cupboard, in this case, the registered nurse looking after the patient should satisfy themselves that the patient is able to maintain security of their medicines. In all cases, CD's should be moved to secure storage in line with MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs policy.
Controlled drugs cupboard
The controlled drugs cupboard is reserved for the storage of Controlled Drugs only.
Nothing should be displayed outside the cupboard that would indicate that controlled drugs are kept inside it (HBN 14-02, 2021).
Please see MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy for full storage requirements.
Bulk fluids
These must be stored in a large cupboard or room that is lockable and locked when not in immediate use. In doing so all storage areas are sufficiently away from patients and the public.

It must be designated a domestically clean area for the storage of large volumes of sterile fluid, including IV infusion solutions, enteral feeds and irrigation solutions. The designated drug room is the preferred option.
Boxes of fluids must be organised in a tidy fashion in a sufficiently sized and strong storage facility.
All bulk fluids must be stored off the floor.

In some areas there is security-tagged/swipe card access with limited public access (i.e. theatres and some intensive care/high dependency units), and therefore fluids are stored in their designated location. This is always approved by pharmacy.
Fluid storage standards are designed to reduce the risks of mis-selection and to encourage stock rotation.
All bags are kept in their original containers (i.e. boxes), even if the box is nearly empty, therefore eliminating any issue of mixed batches/products.
Bags are NEVER decanted into any other container.
Expiry dated labels & product description on boxes should be facing the front where possible. Where the expiry date is obscured it should be clearly re-written on the box (in the form MM/YYYY).
Identical products should be stored together with shortest-dated in front / on top.
Higher percentage products (i.e. 10%, 20% glucose) are physically separate from lower strength products.
Non-intravenous fluids (irrigation, enteral feeds etc.) are physically separate in the storage area.
In clinical areas that use arterial lines, bags of sodium chloride 0.9% for use as arterial line flush must be stored away from fluids for intravenous use, in their original boxed container.
Where any fluid bag is removed from its protective outer pouch/wrapper, and not used immediately, it must be disposed as per pharmaceutical waste. It must never be returned to stock.

Only those fluid solutions in regular use should be stored in a clinical area. If practicality dictates that such solutions must be stored, an additional risk assessment and management plan must be made to prevent their erroneous use. This must be carried out with full pharmacy involvement.
Medical Gases
Medical gases in cylinders must be stored safely and securely to mitigate the following health and safety and diversion risks:
Cylinders are heavy and can cause severe injuries if mishandled
Cylinders contain compressed gas at high pressure and can cause severe injury or death if damage leads to sudden escape of gas
Oxygen supports combustion and increases the risk of fire
Other gases may cause suffocation if used inappropriately or may be subject to theft, diversion and abuse.

Storage of cylinders is monitored by this policy. Healthcare professionals are expected to know what to do if there is a problem with the cylinder. Refer to MSEPO-21130 Medical gases operational policy.

Small size medical gas cylinders (e.g. size C, CD) must be stored in wall- mounted fittings designed for the purpose OR are stored horizontally on specially designed shelving for the purpose which reduces risk of damage.
Larger cylinders are stored in a cage or secured to a fixed structure (i.e. cylinder trolley) by a safety chain/safety bar, at all times.
Areas where oxygen is stored or used display the Trust-approved appropriate signage.
Entonox is liable to theft and must be locked away or in the case of large cylinders anchored to a wall (i.e. by a locked chain).
Medical Gases are also piped in a number of locations and guidance factsheets are to be present by the Area Valve Service Units (AVSU's) in each clinical area.
Nutritional Supplements
Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a prescription only medicine and must be stored in locked medication cupboards, or a medication-only fridge as per the labelling instructions.
Enteral feeds infusion bags/bottles and sip feeds (oral drinking bottles/shots) are classed as food supplements.
They may be stored in unlocked facilities such as open shelving. Patient- specific labelled enteral feeds/ sip feeds may be stored by the bedside pending discharge unlocked.
These should remain in their original containers/boxes at all times to avoid mis-selection and wastage of stock. The only exception is where supplied from pharmacy as a single item.
These should be stored in appropriate temperature conditions as per the labelling instructions.
Warming of fluids in warming cabinets

Some clinical areas, such as theatre and post-operative wards, are permitted to store bags of fluids in a warming cabinet prior to administration. The use of such cabinets will be approved by the site Medication Safety Team prior to use.
It is the responsibility of the nurse-in-charge or equivalent to ensure the cabinet is appropriately monitored and maintained.
Servicing and Calibration
25.3.1  All warming cabinets will be regularly serviced and calibrated to ensure accurate temperature monitoring.
They should be set at not higher than 38°C and must have a working temperature gauge and alarm in operation.
Where either is not operational, both the cabinet and its contents should not be used.

The ward/department manager is responsible for ensuring servicing and calibration is carried out at the specified times by the manufacturer, and can evidence this (i.e. record of when last calibrated/serviced is readily available).
Acceptable temperature range
25.4.1  Warming fluids above 38°C risks microbial contamination.
The acceptable range is 36.5 – 38°C.
Specific pharmacy advice must be sought as to whether fluids may or may not be used.
Temperatures below 36.5°C, whilst pharmaceutically acceptable are likely to be unsuitable to use as a warmed fluid in clinical practice.
Temperature monitoring

25.5.1 The same principles apply exactly for drug room and fridge temperature monitoring. The integrated thermometer should be used for warmer monitoring, as this will be regularly calibrated by the routine servicing.

25.5.2 Routine temperature monitoring is required at least daily and must be evidenced though completion of the log in the designated Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet. This must be done at approximately the same time each day.
25.5.3 There is a monitoring booklet specific for areas with warmers – available from pharmacy.
25.5.4 The current, maximum and minimum temperature must be recorded. Action must be taken where out of range and documented within the booklet.
Storage and Labelling
25.6.1 Certain bags of infusion fluid may be warmed to 38°C provided they remain in their outer wrap.
25.6.2 When stored above 25°C the nominal volume of these bags will decrease and, as a result, the concentration will increase.
25.6.3 In order to minimise this, a limited shelf-life is applicable to all bags placed in the cabinet. As such all products must be labelled with an expiry date before going into the warmer.

25.6.4 Note that revised expiry dates exist for specific warmed products. Different products have different stabilities upon heating according to different manufacturer advice. Advice for current products in use is available from pharmacy.
Freezing of bulk fluids for topical use
In some theatre areas it may be necessary to freeze bulk fluids for topical use during a procedure (e.g. ENT procedures).
Where any bulk fluid is to be frozen, it MUST be clearly marked as ‘FROZEN' on the outer wrap (using a clear label), BEFORE placing in freezer.
Once used during a procedure it must be immediately disposed of and must not return to stock.
Any fluids previously frozen and now defrosted must also be disposed of immediately and NOT returned to stock.
Storage of Medicines for Clinical Emergency
Storage arrangements allow for immediate access to critical medicines in the event of a clinical emergency.
Wards and departments keep supplies of some medicines for life-threatening emergency on the designated resuscitation trolley. This may be in either of the following storage facilities:
Designated trays in a tamper-evident Resuscitation Trolley (designed for the purpose)
Tamper-evident resuscitation medication boxes (limited sites and locations only), usually stored on the resuscitation trolley.

Other emergency medicines will be stocked in the standard medication cupboards/fridges following local cardiopulmonary resuscitation guidelines. This may differ by site according to local requirements.
Please refer to the Resuscitation policy and procedures (or equivalent).

The resuscitation trolley should be situated in a strategic and accessible site and be appropriately covered. Where medicines are stored in boxes they are clearly marked ‘for emergency use', with their contents clearly marked. These will differ according to the specialty, type of clinical area and site.

Where resuscitation boxes are used, they must be replaced immediately on opening. The ward/department should return the opened box to pharmacy in person and collect a replacement. A small supply of such replacement boxes is available in the emergency drug cupboard for out-of-hours use.

Containers of medicines are tamper-evident and not held in locked cupboards or rooms, except where a risk assessment is in place and are reviewed regularly. The risk assessment must consider the level of security and balance this against the need to ensure timely access to medicines when they are required. All associated risk assessments are only valid where signed off by the Medication Safety Team on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist. These will be formally signed off by the Medicines Assurance Group. Risk assessments may be considered appropriate for high-risk areas, such as critical care. Any assessment should be restricted to critical medicines in the event of a clinical emergency.
Emergency department

Where emergency bags or kits are held (e.g. for emergency teams working outside hospitals, or for major incidents), and it is impractical for these to be locked away they should be placed in an area that is most likely to have constant staff presence.
All kits must be tamper evident and once-opened managed as above.
Neither the emergency kits themselves nor their contents should be obvious to the general public.
Operating departments (including Anaesthetic rooms) and areas
performing procedures
Best practice on storage of drugs in Anaesthetic Rooms at the Trust is in line with Royal College of Anaesthetists & Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland guidance.
The storage facilities and requirements set out within this policy also apply to theatres and areas performing procedures (i.e. in a day case setting), with exceptions as per this chapter.

To ensure that medicines are readily available, the appointed Nurse in Charge may delegate control of access. This may be to a qualified deputy, medical practitioner (e.g. anaesthetist) or an ODP. The latter is agreed locally for each site.

Electronic swipe card' access control systems are in place for all routes that allow entry into operating departments/ procedure areas. This limits access to only those with legitimate reasons for access.
Security of Anaesthetic Room medicines / Procedure area medicines
28.5.1  Drug security in these rooms reflects a balance between patient safety, staff protection and security.
Medicines must be readily available during theatre/procedure lists, and as such storage facilities (i.e. drug cupboards) may remain unlocked whilst theatre/procedure clinic is in session.

Medicines are stored in the anaesthetic room rather than the theatre itself and as such drug cupboards may remain unlocked when the anaesthetic room is temporarily unoccupied and the operating theatre is in use. This is essential for immediate easy access to medicines at all times during the procedure.
An unoccupied anaesthetic room should remain visible at all times to those in the operating theatre, usually through windows in the door, where possible.
At the end of the theatre session / procedure clinic (i.e. end of the working day or lunchtime) all medicines must be returned to the lockable and locked medicine cupboards and fridges.
Access to Emergency Medicines

28.6.1  Patient safety must be the paramount consideration. Immediate access to a variety of drugs can sometimes be essential, such that even short delays in drug availability can make a difference to patient outcome.

It is not possible to provide a definitive list of ‘emergency drugs' that should be immediately available at all times, as these vary depending on patient condition and the type of procedure being performed.
There are few drugs commonly stored in anaesthetic room drug cupboards that will not be needed urgently on occasion.

It is common practice to prepare a selection of ‘emergency drugs' that should be immediately available during the course of an anaesthetic/ procedure. As such, specific ‘emergency drugs' for that particular theatre session /procedure clinic can be pre-prepared for the day. They either accompany the patient from the anaesthetic room into the operating theatre (or equivalent process) or should be stored in the anaesthetic room in a manner that maintains their immediate availability.

They must be adequately labelled (full drug name and strength, expiry date etc.), and disposed of appropriately at the end of the session, if not used. Storage must be on separate preparation trays either prepared by an anaesthetist or an ODP/anaesthetic-trained registered nurse.

In the interests of patient safety, cupboards cannot be locked during surgical procedures. Practices can be followed that may minimise medicines security risks, e.g. drugs and fluids prepared in advance for procedures can be kept in closed-door, but unlocked, cupboards. Drugs for the specific patient in theatre/undergoing procedure can be moved from the cupboard and stored on the workbench during that specific procedure.

Certain rarely-used emergency drugs are stored in a central location, serving the entire theatre suite, e.g. dantrolene and intralipid. The location of these drugs is conspicuously signposted throughout the theatre suite.

All local anaesthetic infusions are stored separately from intravenous infusion solutions and other safe segregation practices are used, e.g. paediatric IV fluids, epidural preparations, glucose and perfusion fluids.
Community Midwifery storage & transportation of medicines
Medicines are generally obtained from the hospital pharmacy. They are delivered to the designated area accessible by community midwives within the hospital to await collection (varies by site).
Once medicines are received, by midwives working in the community, they become the responsibility of the specific community midwife, and must be stored safely and securely.
Patients own home
29.3.1  Generally, patient-specific drugs should be stored in the patient's own home. Community Midwives should offer advice on the safe storage of medicines in patients' homes:
In a safe place, away from the sight and reach of children.
Ideally in a locked receptacle or cupboard.
In a dry atmosphere (preferably not a bathroom).
Keeping medicines in the containers they were dispensed in.
Midwife own home

29.4.1 Storing medicines in a midwife's own home is considered exceptional practice. This is only acceptable where the midwife is oncall. Medicines not needed should be brought back into the base hospital site.

29.4.2 Where oncall medicines are stored within the home, security measures should ensure medicines are in a safe place, away from the sight and reach of children, in a dry atmosphere (preferably not a bathroom), away from sources of heat.
During working periods
Non-refrigerated medicines (known as ambient ‘room' temperature stored medicines) will be carried in the midwife's bag or a concealed place in the car avoiding temperature extremes.
Ambient storage is defined as below 25°C.
When not in use the bag must be locked in the car in a concealed position.
Controlled Drugs

29.6.1  It is considered good practice that registrants should not transport CDs in the course of their practice. Patient's requiring controlled drugs are usually referred to hospital or will have the appropriate medication already obtained via prescription at the patient's home. The medication then remains the property of the patient.
Acceptable temperature range
For outside the Trust site the room temperature ‘ambient' definition for temperature storage must be applied.
Items stored in ‘ambient' locations must be kept within the range 15°C – 25°C.

It is recognised that temperatures can fluctuate in cars especially by season. As such a cool bag is suggested to maintain a more even temperature within the acceptable range for the whole year. Cool bags are insulating medicines from the external temperature and do not necessarily require ice blocks inside them. The only requirement that the inside temperature is within the acceptable temperature range.
Temperature monitoring

Storage of drugs above or below the recommended temperature as detailed by the manufacturer is a pharmaceutical quality risk, and therefore the effectiveness of the drug being administered may be affected. Patient's rightly have an expectation that the medicine they receive is safe to use and will be as what the manufacturer has produced.

The same principles apply for temperature monitoring as for storage on the hospital site/s. The Trust-approved thermometers are suitable for this purpose. The thermometer must be stored with the medicines so it monitors the temperature regardless where the medicines bag is stored (i.e. home, car boot, inside car cabin etc.).

Routine temperature monitoring is required at least daily and must be evidenced though completion of a log. A designated Medicines Storage Monitoring Booklet will provide this. Monitoring should be taken at approximately the same time each day.
The current, maximum and minimum temperature must be recorded. Action must be taken where out of range and documented within the booklet.
Refrigerated storage medicines stored at ambient temperature
Where drugs are removed from the fridge and are stored at ambient temperature, this affects the stability of the drug and it will have a vastly reduced expiry date.
Where a pre-pack of medicines is provided by pharmacy, the midwife must note the limited expiry date and ensure it is exchanged before it expires.

Where a pre-pack of medicines is not available the midwife must amend the expiry date when removing from the fridge for ambient (room temperature) storage. Only the expiry date guide is provided by the hospital pharmacy should be used for this purpose.

Such items with a reduced expiry date only apply where temperatures are maintained below 25°C. This is because stability data only supports storage up to this temperature. Storage warmer that this risks treatment failure (reduced effectiveness of drug).
Action to take for REPEATED or SUSTAINED temperatures above range
(Recorded temperature is above 25°C consistently or is expected to be at multiple times periods across season, including heat waves)

29.10.1  Where ambient-stored drugs are stored in cars, it is known that temperatures can easily exceed 25°C, especially during the warmer seasons. As such the following course of action must be taken consistently for every individual drug stored in the warm car:
Check if there is an obvious cause that can be remedied? For example, has the thermometer or probe been positioned incorrectly or is it damaged/ battery empty? If unsure call pharmacy.
Consider if temperature can be maintained below 25°C through use of insulated containers (cool boxes), where not already done. Care must be taken to prevent freezing.
Check on the hospital pharmacy guideline for community midwife storage of medicines for any specific guidance on how to store.

If no specific guidance listed, reduce the expiry date on the package (and all individual ampoules) by 6 months from the date moved to the car (e.g. if expiry is 01/12/2022, then change expiry date to 01/06/2022).
Document in the monitoring booklet what actions taken next to the relevant day.
Ensure all temperatures continue to be monitored and documented daily in the monitoring booklet. This information is critical for any future decisions regarding storage of medicines in this location.
Medical Gas Cylinders (i.e. Entonox)

29.11.1 Entonox must be stored securely. This means locked away at all times. All storage locations (including cars) must be labelled with the appropriate Trust- approved compressed gas warning signs.
29.11.2 If being transported in car boots, cylinders must be fastened to prevent damage. Entonox must be removed from the vehicle overnight and when left unattended for long periods of time.
29.11.3 Cold temperature:

Nitrous oxide mixtures (like Entonox) must be stored in a temperature- controlled environment with the ability to maintain temperatures above 10°C. Where these are transported, cylinders should be maintained above 10°C. Where this is not practical, prior to use, the cylinder must be stored at room temperature for 24 – 48 hours.
Before use, cylinders should be inverted three times before use to ensure the two gases are well mixed.
This risk is reduced by storing the Entonox on the Trust hospital site/s until required.
Training Requirements
Staff training is provided by face-to-face induction by the ward/department manager (or equivalent).
Pharmacy may also provide training support on an adhoc basis in response to audit and department walkabouts in collaboration with the ward/department manager.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Medicines Assurance Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform trust staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the site medication safety team within the site department of pharmacy.
